commentBody: Nice, uncontroversial puzzle.

Enjoyable and quick.  Just 10 seconds off my Friday record, which is a shame since I like long puzzles (I do them in bed and like to be falling asleep before I finish).  Oh well, off to read something tedious now, I suppose.

This week has been pretty meh until now, but I liked this one.

I've never seen TRASH PANDA outside of a crossword puzzle, although this isn't the first time I've seen it so I knew it right away.  I guess I'm learning things from crosswords!

A lively puzzle with some fresh entries and some interesting clues for some old standbys (EPEES, MAGMA).  I liked BENEFITSPACKAGE, AIRMARSHALL, MRRIGHTNOW, and PAGETURNER.  I also enjoyed prepares for a ‚Äúwild‚Äùnight (NAPS) crossing ‚ÄúWilde‚Äù thing (POEM).

If we have these plurals:
Passers by
Attorneys general
Daughters in law

Then should we have ‚Äúmeets cute‚Äù?
Haha, how to turn a cute idea into crusty grammatical stodginess.
Also: just kidding.
I loved this one! Lots of good, fun fill. Had IOS instead of CPU for faaar too long. Plugged along here and there but it was really enjoyable. Thanks, Greg & Glenn. Happy Friday, y‚Äôall!
I was stumped with OXES. I‚Äôve only known ‚Äòoxen‚Äô as the plural of ox, and even then, it didn‚Äôt quite fit the clue for me.
fun, but over pretty quickly for a Friday.  New best time, and half my average time.  Thoroughly enjoyable nonetheless.

I‚Äôve been introduced to ONAHEATER and NERTS and I can‚Äôt say I enjoyed their company very much. Hmmph.

While TRASH PANDA has been a relatively common term for a raccoon due to their frequent forays into dumpsters and other garbage receptacles, there was one that worked its way into a liquor store in VA, and was found drunk and passed out in the store's bathroom. It was promptly called TRASHED PANDA, and its photo, emblazoned on some tees and sweatshirts, has raised over $170K for the VA animal rescue organization that took him in. https://washingtonian.com/2025/12/09/viral-trashed-panda-raccoon-raises-over-170k-for-virginia-animal-shelter/
Shockingly doable. Fun fill.
I'm a little embarrassed that I knew "meet cute", but I learned it from watching The Office (not romcoms).

On a heater ? Never heard it before.

For some reason I had more trouble on Wednesday than Thursday, this week.  Today‚Äôs seemed scary to begin with, but then everything just fell into place, except for  ‚Äòheater‚Äô

("Your knowledge is going to crater!")
"No, I promise I conduit!")

Really enjoyable! My personal favourites were the clues for CIGARBOXES and PAGETURNER

ONAHEATER

For 37D, I confidently filled in "rats." Turns out I wasn't far off, in fact, as a 2023 study estimated the NYC rat population at around 3 million. For more, see: - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rats_in_New_York_City Guess there's a Wikipedia page on almost any topic.
Shockingly,I caught the wave of this puzzle. Fun!

In about 12 hours, we will SETUPCAMP in the Serengeti. Will we see GNUS and so much more. And last week, I saw all the Nelson Mandela sites in South Africa, no IDRIS Elba though.

My streak survived the Surinam rainforest, let's see if it survives the Tanzanian savanna...

A couple of look-ups, a couple of flyers, and the fog started to clear.  A real pea souper for a while, but when it started to fall into place it felt like hot skis on a downhill slope, faster and faster, and actually quite thrilling (was I ONAHEATER?  IVENOIDEA). 

Thanks Greg and Glenn, I loved it.
What the heck is a NERT?

OXES?

ON A HEATER?

I enjoyed most of the clueing - the challenge of this grid may have been slightly less than what I expect on Friday, but at least it was created by misdirection rather than spamming trivia, as is sometimes the case.
YOU BETTER BELIEVE IT! Somebody mixed up the Friday puzzle pile with the Mondays. Easiest Friday ever. Felt even easier than a Monday.
Felt like I was right on the same wavelength as the constructors today! I‚Äôm guessing at least one of them is a programmer, with UNIX, CPU, and CODE all in there :)

I was so convinced of _____NOVEL that it lead to INVEST__PACKAGE which obviously is insane. 

This is one of those "waterfall" puzzles where a few key hits unraveled the rest quickly. All really started bottom right, zig zagging up from there. Had a better time today than other days this week, pretty neat!

tuesday called and it wants its puzzle back.

on the other hand AIRMARSHAL for Stealthy flier was "niiiice"-inducing.

i reached my first 1,000-day streak today!

i don‚Äôt post much here, but i am thankful for these puzzles & this community every day. ü´∂

Nerts to all you non-dice playing constructors but for the umpteeth time (39a) rolls of 2,3 and 12 are not losing/bad/bummer outcomes. Like all rolls they can win or lose. 30+ years as a box man and I can assure you players win far more money when these numbers are rolled

Fun puzzle, I enjoyed it! Fast, but I had several wrong answers, like moccasins before TUBESOCKS, side before AREA, and shoe and iron before BOOT.

A lot of nerdy fill that I cottoned onto quickly. But the one that made me think the puzzle was reading my mind was MRRIGHTNOW. Just yesterday I was telling a story about someone I called Mr Right Now. I read the clue and thought "nah... but hmm, that fits."

I've said NERTS a lot. In my head it can also be spelled nertz. Clues that include the phrase "old-timey" apparently now refer to my lifetime. Hoo boy.

Pointless nit: MAGMA doesn't bubble until it reaches the surface, at which point, of course, it's lava. Yes I got the answer, yes it's a perfectly fine clue, but I don't want anyone thinking there's a giant cavern beneath the crust with bubbling magma in it. That would be so wrong.
Lots of clever clues in this one, which had me stuck on a near empty grid for a while before everything fell into place swiftly. Fun :)
ICEE isn't necessarily a fruity drink. Slush is redundant. It's just an ICEE.
"Bummer at a casino game" was my favourite clue. Fun puzzle throughout though!

This puzzle was delicious, IMNSHO, full of word play, puns and misdirection.

Along with the clues/answers that Will (Hi Will!) pointed out, I thought 16A was a super clue, and 61A pretty funny.

Thanks to Mr. Snitkin and Mr. Davis!

(I have taken Will Shortz‚Äôs words to heart and am embracing ONAHEATER, which is new to me. I would have clued it ‚ÄúWhere to sit when you have constipation‚Äù. IVENOIDEA about the meaning relating to betting. As for OXES, well, I raised half an eyebrow, but we Brits are used to the language being butchered - there are no sacred cows!)
MEETCUTES? What am i missing?

Although it went more quickly than I‚Äôd‚Äôve liked, I loved the puzzle. I even checked afterwards whether it wasn‚Äôt a Robin Weintraub brainchild‚Äîwhich is a high bar for a fun grid. 

Having started in the SE corner, I thought that the [Wilde thing] was going to be ‚Äòquip,‚Äô which would‚Äôve made [prepares for a wild night, maybe] ‚ÄòBBQs,‚Äô and I thought to myself: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt had *that* combination since college. Other folks must be having a lot more fun with their veggie burgers than hubs and I.‚Äù Still, it would‚Äôve been a great cross. Too bad Wilde wrote POEMs, too. 

About that MR. RIGHT NOW‚Äîand this is in no way a gripe about the puzzle. 

[clears throat for rant] 

May I just say that I loathe the term and don‚Äôt really understand the concept? As for the term itself, I‚Äôd‚Äôve thought that with all the care we take with how we speak about women, we‚Äôd‚Äôve retired the term because we want to be respectful to men, too. As for the concept, why would anyone want to have a relationship with someone she thinks of as a placeholder? I‚Äôve been married for almost half my life now, but I remember dating. There were lots of great (and less than great) guys I saw only a few times because we didn‚Äôt click 100%. What‚Äôs with the idea of dating anyone ‚Äúfor now‚Äù for an extended period of time?

These are rhetorical questions, by the way, idle musings as I sit in traffic in the back of an Uber. 

Bottom line: a great puzzle to (almost) usher in the weekend.

Rom-com plot points

MEETCUTES???

Am I missing something?

This was fun.

Some of it was areas that were fast fill-ins, that is, whoosh fun. Some of it was wordplay, which sparked the cluing throughout, and brought smiles. Some of it was fun answers like HECK YEAH, ON A HEATER, even LURID.

It was even fun having an area that I could hardly dent (the NW), right at the start, but having the faith that I would come around later and eventually fill it in (because the Times editing is superb), then indeed doing just that.

It was fun being reminded of dogs with PUPPY LOVE, LAB, even a backward PAWS, because the dogs in my family have so enriched my life. I was just thinking yesterday, as I was petting my dog Teddy, that dogs are a remarkable gift to mankind, and I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not alone in thinking this.

It was fun seeing a new-to-the-Times grid design that was wonderfully flowy, with no isolated corners.

I really liked MR RIGHT NOW; PAGE TURNER; and MEET CUTES.¬† ¬†I was looking for some kind of drone-y contraption for "stealthy flier" -- and AIR MARSHALL was a wonderful surprise.¬† Great clue.


Not wild about the CRUSADED¬†clue.¬† Today's crusaders are usually pushing a cause or an agenda rather than leading a charge.

Re 22D:¬† There's a triple kealoa to be found in LOAF, LOLL and LAZE.

To CUT IN on a dance floor is "rude"???¬† Back in the day, it was the height of male politesse -- all that tapping the other male lightly on the shoulder and the soft-spoken "May I's?".¬† Of course, that dance floor etiquette had begun to die even in my youth.¬† Still done in the 1950s when I was at Viola Wolf's Dancing School (the girls loved the classes; the boys hated them), no one was cutting in on the energetic dancing of the 1960s.¬† But "rude"????¬† If it's that rude, why has the custom even persisted?

A lively puzzle that I found on the easy side for a Friday.

Overall I think it was a really good puzzle.  After like 15 minutes I only had like 5-6 answers and was thinking of giving up.   Then I got PUPPYLOVE and from that the entire top half of the puzzle clicked in sequence.

I do have a little bit of an issue with the NERT/MEETCUTES crossing.  I tried googling NERT after and it came up with nothing except acronyms for organizations that had nothing to do with oaths, what the heck is A NERT?!

And I find the word 'MEETCUTES' just a little bit cringey.  I don't know what it is, it feels like something your overly nosy aunt who never stops talking about her 400 dolls might try to push on you.

I'm fixin' to check the Key because of the NW corner...2D/14A.

I'm bloodied but unbowed...  but I must say, I got off on the wrongest possible foot--being over-excited about putting in the TRASH PANDA...so hilarious! Also the name of a minor league baseball team we have seen play.... anyway, I gleefully entered it at 61A.  It fit beautifully.  
Needless to say, I quickly found myself in a quagmire.  No explanation except that I had not yet had my cup of coffee.

Aaaand the Key somewhat shamed me:  I know POCO a POCO (Bit by bit) but have never seen/heard 14A, and 2D was simply beyond me.  I had APES at 19A, which was not helpful.
So, three wrong letters.  I read off the clue/answer for 2D, and
DHubby indignantly said, "Nobody uses UNIX as an 'alternative to Windows,' it being an ancient operating system for mainframe computers.")  LINIX, yes, UNIX, no.  Except, of course, for today.  (Did Will hold this puzzle up THAT long??)  

This doesn't make my Fail any less, but I tried as best I could, so there's that.  I really enjoyed the clever clues and Aha Moments.  And nobody was trying to make me accept entries that were rendered wrong due to a pet theme.  That whole thing was like a cook's turning out a nice meal but leaving the kitchen strewn with pots, pans, scraps, utensils, spills, and dirty dishes.

P.S.  Best Misdirect (for me):
37D   2.3 million, eh?   Must be DOGS! No.  CATS!  No.  PETS!  No.  
Crosses to the rescue.

@Andrzej History and law? Yeah, I‚Äôm the one sitting there thinking hmm I wonder if that‚Äôs true. Or just believing it. 

Caves exist, but they are extremely shallow (geologically speaking). The earth is a solid sphere well before you get to magma. By solid I mean geometrically, not solid, liquid, gas. The spherical shape is a clue. For really big things like planets, gravity within the planet is so strong that the resulting shape is a sphere. So that means that gravity will make it solid, too. It smushes everything together into a ball. 

As for the bubbling, magma is under a lot of pressure until it comes to the surface. So the gases trapped within the magma can‚Äôt get out until pressure is released at the surface. And back to splitting that hair, the magma is now lava. 

I know, way more than anyone wanted to know.
